bibl.idno: The Philip S. Hench Walter Reed/Yellow Fever Collection [manuscript] / [collected by] Philip S. Hench ; HEALTHSCI MS-1.

div1.head: Newspaper clipping, [19--]
div1.p:
The dedication yesterday of a new
surgical building for the Johns Hopkins
Medical School and the unveiling of a
tablet in memory of a member of the
hospital staff who gave his life in the
cause of science were made the occa-
sion of interesting addresses by a num-
ber of leaders in the medical world.
By the addition of this building to the
large group the facilities of the school
for instruction in surgery are greatly
increased, and those in charge of the
institution can feel gratified at the re-
sults of their efforts. By thus increasing
the equipment and adding to its accom-
modations for instruction the school
opens the way to larger classes, to more
students from all parts of the coun-
try. The work of the men who have
been at its head has given the school a
world-wide fame, and though Dr. Osler,
one of the ablest of the number, will
soon leave this country for England,
the work here will continue on the same
advanced lines and no doubt with the
same excellent results.

Though the losses sustained by the
hospital in the February fire were very
large and for a time threatened it with
permanent embarrassment, through a
generous gift from Mr. John D. Rocke-
feller and by other donations its finan-
cial standing has been assured, and it
may soon be able to even enlarge the
field of its operations. Similar conditions
prevail at the Hopkins University, now
at the opening of a new scholastic
year, and both of these magnificent in-
stitutions, founded in the name of higher
education and for the advancement and
betterment of mankind, have before
them a future full of promise, sure to
be great in accomplishments.
